, twenty miles west of its sister city

. Much of the major industry in the area is Oil and Gas related. As such, the Midland/Odessa area is colloquially known as the petroplex. Much of the attractions you will find in the area are in Midland, so if you're visiting Odessa, the Midland article deserves a look as well.
Odessa is located at the junction of US Highway 385 and Interstate 20 in West Texas. Heading east on I-20 will take you through cities like
. Heading west on I-20 takes you through some of the most barren parts of Texas at 80 MPH (the fastest speed limit in the nation) on your way to
. Going south on 385 will take you to
, while heading north on US 385 will take you through the

value: , 9506 Laforce Blvd. Ten miles east of Odessa. Southwest Airlines is the only mainline airline service to the area. It provides direct flights to Dallas-Love, Houston-Hobby, Las Vegas and Albuquerque. United Express provides service to Denver and Houston-Intercontinental, and American Eagle provides service to/from Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport.

. Odessa and Midland have a shared bus system that currently does not travel between cities. Inter-city routes serving Midland International and both cities are planned to start soon. There are 6 bus routes that serve Odessa, and each bus route runs once hourly. Fares for Adults 19+ are $1.25, Children 6-18 and students with a valid ID are $1.00, Seniors 60+ and people with disabilities are $0.60 and children 5 and under are Free. Monthly passes and Paratransit are available too. EZRider runs 6:15 AM-7:10 PM M-F and 6:15 AM-6:10 PM Sat.
content= A renovated 1951 classic movie theater that shows classic movies and showcases live music.  Located in downtown Odessa.
directions=From Interstate 20- Take Exit 121 and head north on Loop 338 to University Ave. Take a left on to University. Museum will be on right near next stop light.
content=There is a permanent collection as well as rotating exhibits.
content=The largest jackrabbit in the world, a 10-foot-tall statue that is the unofficial mascot of the region.
content=Student and Art Faculty shows are presented here on a semi-regular basis. Artwork may be purchased and starving college students will be very appreciative.

content=Formerly housed downtown, this museum suffered from the move. Currently, there is a permanent exhibit of memorabilia from each presidency, however it is not nearly as vast as it was. There has also been the addition of George W. Bush's childhood home onto the grounds.
, built in 1892 and moved to Odessa in 1950. The depot is part of the Barn Door Steakhouse.
content=A full-size replica of the original neolithic
content=Turn of the century home with rotating exhibits on various aspects of West Texas life.
content=Full-sized reproduction of the Globe Theatre of
. Various productions throughout the year. In addition there is a replica of the Anne Hathaway Cottage which Shakespeare built for his love.
content=Music City Mall has 4 anchor tenants (Sears, JC Penney, Dillard's, and Burlington Coat Factory), an 11 screen movie theater, an indoor ice rink, local CBS affiliate, carousel and food court.
address=3952 East 42nd Street, Ste. I (Santa Fe Shopping Center)
hours=Mon-Sat 11A-7P, extended hours on Tue. until, roughly, midnight
content=Offering CDs, and musical instruments, there is also a "Tuesday Nite Pickin' Party" which is open to the public.
content=This is a strip mall at the busiest intersection in Odessa. Stores include H.E.B., Big 5 Sporting Goods, Ross Dress for Less, GameStop, Hastings, Target and Office Depot.

Due to its proximity to Mexico, Odessa has quite a bit of authentic Mexican and Tex-Mex. Most of these authentic restaurants are found off the beaten path, but are usually well worth the trip.
Many chain restaurants have set up shop in Odessa. It's not hard to find a McDonalds or Burger King.

value: content=Ben's is a local restaurant serving Tex-Mex.
address=4945 E. 42nd Street; 1310 E. 8th.; 1701 West County Road.

content=Rosa's is a favorite among locals. The restaurant started in this area before spreading out all over Texas. Try the Fajitas and the tortillas made in the restaurant. There is a window into the kitchen where you can watch the tortillas being made.
address=1627 E. 8th St.; 2701 Andrews Hwy.; 3901 N. Grandview Ave.; 1705 W County Rd.
content=Bush's Chicken is a new entry to Odessa but has gotten a strong following amongst locals. Be sure to try their Tender Rolls.
content=Yet another local Mexican Food restaurant. Very popular amongst locals.
content=Much of the menu consists of Southern and Homestyle cooking, such as chicken strips, steak fingers, mashed potatoes, fried catfish, etc.

content=Mi Piaci serves Italian cuisine. The owners of the restaurant are from Albania and create an authentic experience when eating at their restaurant. Most plates are around $10, but if you're on a budget, or want something simple, try the pizza. The Mi Piaci pizza is probably some of the best in town, and certainly the best pizza by a locally owned restaurant.
content=Ajuua's serves authentic Tex-Mex in a sit-down atmosphere. The restaurant just recently moved from their old location next door into their new building.
name=The Barn Door and Pecos Depot Steakhouse
content=The Barn Door is probably the most reputable and high-class restaurant in town. The food is typical steakhouse fare.
content=3075 E. Business Loop-20. Continental breakfast.
content=6201 E. Business Loop-20. Free airport shuttle.

).  This National Natural Landmark is the third biggest crater in the country and sixth in the world. Self-paced tours available 9AM-5PM daily. Tu-Sa 9AM-5PM, Su 1PM-5PM. Free.
